title: Fix prefix mismatch error in bd sync with --rename-on-import flag
description: The GitHub Action fails during bd sync with 'prefix mismatch detected' error because some issues in the JSONL have 'family-' prefix while the database expects 'family-panel-' prefix.
design:
Error from workflow:
```
Error importing: import failed: exit status 1
Import failed: prefix mismatch detected: database uses 'family-panel-' 
but found issues with prefixes: [family- (3 issues)] 
(use --rename-on-import to automatically fix)
```

Root cause: During the sync operation, bd tries to pull from remote and import the JSONL, but discovers a prefix mismatch. Some issues have 'family-' prefix while the database was initialized with 'family-panel-' prefix.

Solution: Add --rename-on-import flag to bd sync command to automatically fix prefix mismatches during import:

```yaml
bd sync --rename-on-import
```

This flag tells bd to automatically rename issues to match the database's configured prefix during the import phase of the sync operation.
acceptance_criteria:
- bd sync runs with --rename-on-import flag
- Prefix mismatches are automatically fixed during import
- No import errors
- Workflow completes successfully
- Issues.jsonl is properly committed and pushed

title: Configure git identity before bd sync in GitHub Action
description: The GitHub Action fails during bd sync with 'Author identity unknown' error because bd sync attempts to commit changes but git user.name/user.email aren't configured yet at that point in the workflow.
design:
Error from workflow:
```
Error committing: git commit failed: exit status 128
Author identity unknown
fatal: empty ident name not allowed
```

Root cause: bd sync tries to commit changes to git (as seen in the output "Committing changes to git..."), but git config user.name/user.email are set in a later step.

Solution: Move the git config commands to run BEFORE the bd sync command, either:
1. Add a separate step after "Initialize beads database" to configure git
2. Or set git config within the "Close beads issue" step before running bd sync

Recommended approach: Add git config setup right after initializing beads database so it's available for all bd commands that might need it.
acceptance_criteria:
- Git user.name and user.email are configured before bd sync runs
- bd sync can successfully commit changes
- No git identity errors
- Workflow completes successfully
- Issues.jsonl is properly committed and pushed
notes: Waiting for PR #7 review. Work complete: Added 'Configure git identity' step after initializing beads database to set git user.name and user.email before bd sync runs. Removed duplicate git config from later step. This fixes the 'Author identity unknown' error when bd sync tries to commit changes.

title: Add bd sync command after closing issue in GitHub Action
description: The GitHub Action reports no changes to commit after running bd close because changes aren't immediately flushed to issues.jsonl. Need to add 'bd sync' command to immediately export changes before committing.
design:
According to beads documentation:
- bd automatically exports to issues.jsonl after 5 seconds (debounce)
- 'bd sync' command immediately flushes pending changes to JSONL
- Git hooks provide zero-lag sync but aren't available in GitHub Actions

Solution: Add 'bd sync' command after 'bd close' in the workflow to immediately flush the database changes to issues.jsonl before attempting to commit.

Workflow change:
```yaml
- name: Close beads issue
  run: |
    bd close ${{ issue_id }} --reason "..." --json
    bd sync  # Immediately flush to issues.jsonl
```
acceptance_criteria:
- bd sync command runs after bd close
- Changes are immediately flushed to issues.jsonl
- Git detects changes to commit
- Updated issues.jsonl is committed and pushed
- Workflow completes successfully
notes: Waiting for PR #6 review. Work complete: Added 'bd sync' command after 'bd close' in GitHub Action workflow to immediately flush database changes to issues.jsonl, bypassing the 5-second debounce timer. This ensures git can detect and commit the updated issues.jsonl file.

title: Fix GitHub Action to work with beads database not tracked in git
description: The GitHub Action still fails with "no beads database found" even after setting BEADS_DIR. The issue is that beads.db file is not tracked in git (only issues.jsonl is tracked), so the action needs to either initialize from issues.jsonl or use a different approach.
design:
Root cause: The .beads/beads.db file is not tracked in git (it's in .gitignore). Only .beads/issues.jsonl is tracked. When the GitHub Action checks out the repo, there's no database file, so bd can't operate.

Possible solutions:
1. Run `bd init` in the workflow before trying to close issues - this should create the database and import from issues.jsonl
2. Use `bd import` to explicitly import the issues.jsonl into a new database
3. Modify .beads/.gitignore to track the database file (not recommended - database is binary and large)

Recommended approach: Add a step to run `bd init` before the "Close beads issue" step. The bd daemon will automatically import from issues.jsonl when it finds it.
acceptance_criteria:
- GitHub Action successfully finds/creates beads database
- bd close command executes successfully
- Issues.jsonl is properly updated after closing
- Workflow completes successfully when PR is merged
- No manual database setup needed
notes: Waiting for PR #5 review. Work complete: Added step to run 'bd init' in GitHub Action workflow to create database from tracked issues.jsonl file. This solves the "no beads database found" error since the database file itself is not tracked in git.

title: Set up Playwright for E2E testing and development observation
description: Configure Playwright for end-to-end browser testing and to enable Claude Code to observe and interact with the running application during development.
design:
Playwright setup:
- Install @playwright/test and browsers (Chromium, Firefox, WebKit)
- Configure playwright.config.ts with baseURL for localhost:3000
- Set up test directory structure (/tests/e2e or /e2e)
- Configure test scripts in package.json

Development observation features:
- Headed mode configuration for Claude Code to see browser
- Screenshot/video capture capabilities
- Network request inspection
- Console log capture

E2E testing capabilities:
- Critical user flows (login, chore assignment, screen time tracking)
- Cross-browser testing
- Visual regression testing (optional)
- CI integration with GitHub Actions

Example tests to create:
- Authentication flow test
- Parent assigns chore to kid flow
- Kid completes chore and earns screen time flow
- Screen time countdown and lockout flow

Commands:
- npm run test:e2e - Run E2E tests headless
- npm run test:e2e:ui - Run with Playwright UI mode
- npm run test:e2e:headed - Run headed for Claude Code observation
- npm run test:e2e:debug - Debug mode with inspector
acceptance_criteria:
- Playwright is installed and configured
- playwright.config.ts exists with proper settings
- Test directory structure is set up
- At least 2 example E2E tests exist
- Tests can run headless in CI
- Tests can run headed for development/observation
- Screenshot capability works
- Documentation on writing new E2E tests
- Claude Code can observe running app via headed tests

title: Fix database inconsistencies with issue ID prefixes
description: The beads database has inconsistent issue ID prefixes - some issues use 'family-panel-' prefix while others use different prefixes. Need to standardize all issues to use the correct 'family-panel-' prefix.
design:
The GitHub Action revealed that the database has issues with inconsistent prefixes:
- Expected prefix: 'family-panel-'
- Found issues with prefix: 'family-' (3 issues)

This causes import failures during sync operations.

Solution: Manually review and fix the issues.jsonl file to ensure all issues use the 'family-panel-' prefix consistently. This may involve:
1. Checking issues.jsonl for any inconsistent prefixes
2. Using bd commands or manual editing to fix prefix issues
3. Ensuring the database and JSONL are in sync with consistent prefixes
4. Committing the corrected issues.jsonl
acceptance_criteria:
- All issues in issues.jsonl use 'family-panel-' prefix consistently
- No prefix mismatch errors when importing
- Database and JSONL are in sync
- GitHub Action can successfully sync without prefix errors
notes: Waiting for PR #8 review. Work complete: Updated beads database tracking files (issues.jsonl and deletions.jsonl) to ensure all issues use consistent 'family-panel-' prefix. This resolves prefix mismatch errors that were preventing the GitHub Action from successfully syncing and committing issue closures.

title: Fix GitHub Action permissions to allow pushing updated issues.jsonl
description: The GitHub Action fails when trying to push the updated issues.jsonl back to the repository with 'Permission denied' error for github-actions[bot].
design:
Error from workflow:
```
Error pushing: git push failed: exit status 128
remote: Permission to brennon/family-panel.git denied to github-actions[bot].
fatal: unable to access 'https://github.com/brennon/family-panel/': The requested URL returned error: 403
```

Root cause: The GitHub Action workflow doesn't have write permissions to push changes back to the repository. The default GITHUB_TOKEN needs explicit permissions.

Solution: Add permissions block to the workflow job to grant contents write permission:

```yaml
jobs:
  close-issue:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      contents: write
      pull-requests: read
```

This grants the workflow permission to:
- Read pull requests (to extract PR title)
- Write contents (to push updated issues.jsonl back to main)
acceptance_criteria:
- GitHub Action has write permissions
- Can successfully push updated issues.jsonl to main
- No permission denied errors
- Workflow completes successfully when PR is merged
notes: Waiting for PR review. Work complete: Added permissions block to GitHub Action workflow to grant contents:write permission, allowing github-actions[bot] to push updated issues.jsonl back to main branch after closing beads issues.
